thread.title: Rough start expected for Aussie market
thread.title_full: Rough start expected for Aussie market

title: Rough start expected for Aussie market
text:
Mon, Jul 27, 2015, 7:35 AM NZST - New Zealand Markets open in 2 hrs 25 mins Rough start expected for Aussie market AAP – 16 hours ago View Photo 

The Australian share market is tipped to continue its downward slide and open the week 45 to 50 points lower following falls in global stocks. 
AMP Capital chief economist Shane Oliver predicts a rough start on Monday after both European and US shares dropped about one per cent on Friday. 
"We'll probably have a fairly weak start to trade, basically on the back of worries about global growth, particularly China, falling commodity prices and earnings in the US," he said. 
"Then the market will take its lead from other factors." 
The Australian market closed lower for a third straight day on Friday, with the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index ending down 24.2 points at 5,566.1. 
The dip followed news that a key gauge of Chinese manufacturing activity touched a 15-month low in July. 
Looking ahead, investors will be focused on Wednesday's meeting of the US Federal Reserve, which is not expected to raise interest rates this time around. 
Closer to home, Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens' speech to the Boao Forum for Asia Financial Cooperation Conference in Sydney on Thursday will also be watched closely. 
On the same day export and import price figures for the June quarter are tipped to show another sharp fall on the back of the slump in commodity prices. 
Meanwhile June credit growth figures due on Friday should remain fairly moderate, Dr Oliver said. 
Ten-year bond yields are expected to drift further below the 2.81 per cent mark reached on Friday after a global fall. 
And the Australian dollar is also tipped to continue its slow slide after dropping below 73 US cents last week for the first time since 2009, to 72.78 cents. 
"In an environment of weak commodity prices and where the Fed is likely to raise interest rates and we're at risk of cutting them again, the direction for the Australian dollar is likely to remain down," Dr Oliver said. @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Robb heading to Hawaii for TPP talks AAP 
Trade Minister Andrew Robb hopes negotiations in Hawaii this week will mean aloha to the much anticipated 12-country …
